bioghist.p: Father John Joseph Fedigan (1842-1908) was born in Rathbran, Ireland. He studied at Saint Maryâ€™s College in Wilmington, Delaware, before entering the Augustinian novitiate at Ghent, Belgium. He was ordained to the priesthood in 1868. During his forty years as a priest, Father Fedigan held many positions in the Province of Saint Thomas of Villanova. In 1874, he was the first Augustinian to serve in Carthage, New York, and became the first Rector there. He was also elected Definitor for American Augustinians at several chapters. Father Fedigan served as president of Villanova College from 1878 to 1880, and in 1887 he was elected Provincial. In this position, he raised more than $275,000 to erect a new college building and Augustinian Monastery at Villanova. These buildings were completed in 1900 and 1901, respectively. From 1902 to 1906, he served as Prior at Our Mother of Good Counsel, Bryn Mawr, Pennsylvania, after which he returned to the monastery at Villanova. Fedigan Hall, a residence building at Villanova University, is named in his honor.

scopecontent.p: The John Joseph Fedigan papers consist of flyers for fundraising campaigns for the Villanova University. One requests funds for the erection of a new college building and Augustinian Monastery. The other flyer requests funds for the erection of a marble statute of St. Augustine and a grotto in honor of the Blessed Mother.
